result.execSummary:
The defendant Charmaine S. Fisher was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Charmaine S. Fisher is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Charmaine S. Fisher was found guilty of Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Huber allowed.  Unless work crew is expressly prohibited by the Court, an inmate serving time as a condition of probation is eligible for work crew and may receive a credit of one day for every 3 days of work performed.

miscConds.notes: If probation or extended supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.  Collections may include income assignment.  This applies to all counts and financial obligations.

Obey all of the rules and regulations of supervising probation agent.  Pay supervision fees.  Do not possess or consume alcoholic beverages and do not have alcoholic beverages within the residence.  Do not be in taverns or on any premises licensed for the sale of intoxicating beverages, except restaurants or grocery stores.  Do not possess or consume controlled substances, except by prescription.  Submit voluntarily to random tests of blood, breath or urine.  Participate in counseling deemed appropriate by your agent, which may include: alcohol/drug, anger management/DV counseling, psychiatric/psychological, AODA Assessment and follow-through with recommended treatment.  Actively search for employment, be employed or attend an educational institution or vocational training program.  Obtain GED or H.S.E.D. during term of probation.
**  Pay all court costs including all applicable surcharges.  If unpaid financial obligations remain at discharge or revocation, civil judgment to be entered.   Submit a DNA sample (unless previously provided).
** Pay DNA surcharges.

records.addlTxt: Petition and Stipulation to Waive Appearance and Hearing and Order Extending Probation for Unpaid Court Obligations.  Probation extended to 5/19/17 or until all court obligations are completed, whichever comes first.

Attorney James Kraus appeared for the State. Defendant, Charmaine S. Fisher, appeared with Attorney James L. Allen.  Probation Agent Priscell Macias in court.  Clerk: PT
Both the State and Agent Macias recommend DE's probation be extended for 6 months.  Atty Allen objects stating DE has financial issues.   Court finds DE has not made a good faith effort to pay her financial court obligations so motion is granted and DE's probation is extended for 6 months.  Agent Macias to draft the paperwork for today's hearing

Order Extending Probatrion for 6 Months from May 19, 2016 to November 19, 2016
Amended
For Restitution order - signed by ADA M Drees

Attorney Emily Trigg appeared for the State. Defendant, Charmaine S. Fisher, appeared with Attorney James L. Allen.  Probation Agent Priscilla Macias in court.  Clerk: PT
ADA Trigg concurs with Agt Macias request to extend DE's probation as DE owes restitution and hasn't fully satisfied her financial obligations.  DE objects to the extension.  Upon hearing arguments court extends DE's probation for 6 months.  Court has no objection to terminating probation early if restitution and financial obligations are paid in full.  Atty Trigg will draft an order extending probation for the court to review and sign.

Proposed Restitution Findgins of Fact and Conclusions of Law -  - Restitution in the amount of: $319.88 Court did not order restittuion for the medallion lost by other victim
Signed by Comm Dowse on 4/27/2016
Restitution Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law.  Restitution of $319.88 to be paid to the victim.

Attorney Margaret Drees appeared for the State.  Def. appeared with Atty James Allen.  Clerk K. Zirbel.  Count 1 - Dismissed on State motion.  Count 2 - Plea of guilty; found guilty by the Court.  Sentenced to serve 30 days in Co. Jail w/Huber; sentence stayed, placed on probation for 6 months w/conditions.  Restitution hearing to be scheduled to determine restitution due.  Defendant is ordered to submit a DNA sample; written notice provided to defendant.
